Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing Burial/Exhumation Models for the Evolution of a (U)HP Terrane in an Orogenic Upper Plate, Liverpool Land, East Greenland
Award.AbstractNarration:
A fundamental difficulty faced by geologists studying the evolution of large mountain ranges is the inability to directly observe the types of rock and deformation patterns that are found at deep crustal levels beneath active mountains. One way to overcome this difficulty is to study ancient mountain ranges that have since been inverted or eroded, and currently expose the deepest structural levels of a mountain range at the surface. The rocks of Liverpool Land (LL), East Greenland, expose the roots to the Caledonides, a mountain range that spanned the length of Greenland, and formed as Scandinavia collided with North America in the time span from about 440 to 360 million years ago. This collaborative effort between faculty and graduate and undergraduate students at Queens College and Cal Poly San Luis Obispo, with assistance from Norwegian geologists, will determine the origin and subsequent deformation history of rocks from the roots of the Caledonides, to better understand the processes of mountain building during continental collision. The results of this project will be of particular interest to researchers studying deformation in actively deforming mountain belts like the Himalaya.

Field and laboratory analysis of high pressure and ultra-high-pressure (UHP) gneisses from Liverpool Land will be used to test models for the subduction and exhumation of UHP terranes in the overriding plates of collisional orogens. Liverpool Land has been correlated with Laurentia, implying it was situated in the upper plate during the Caledonian Orogeny as Baltica subducted beneath. Previous work by these investigators in LL has identified eclogites and mantle-derived garnet peridotites possibly correlated with Baltica in addition to a tectonostratigraphic suture between a younger UHP terrane and an older mid-crustal gneiss terrane. These discoveries challenge generally accepted models for the formation of UHP terranes where continental lithosphere is pulled to mantle depths by negatively buoyant oceanic lithosphere, as well as models for their exhumation in the footwalls of lithospheric-scale normal faults. We propose a structural, geochemical, and geo-thermo-chronologic study of the LL gneiss complexes to 1) define the tectonic setting and metasomatic history of the mantle wedge incorporated into the LL terrane, 2) determine Laurentian versus Baltic provenance of the LL gneiss complexes, and 3) characterize the kinematics and timing of tectonostratigraphic sutures responsible for exhumation in LL. The proposed work promises to shed light on geodynamic processes including the possibility of multiple UHP events during the closure of ocean basins, crust-mantle interaction and exchange during orogeny, and lower to midcrustal melting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most exciting geologic discoveries of the past 30 years is the realization that during large mountain building events, rocks from the Earth’s surface can be buried to depths of greater than 100 km and then rapidly exhumed back to the surface as the mountain range evolves. This rapid burial and exhumation process has tectonic implications for the growth and ultimate collapse of large mountain belts, as well as more fundamental implications for how major and trace elements are portioned within the Earth’s exterior crust and interior mantle. However, a fundamental difficulty faced by geologists studying this burial and exhumation process is the inability to directly observe the types of rock and deformation patterns that are found at deep crustal levels beneath active mountains like the Himalaya and Tibet. One way to overcome this difficulty is to study ancient mountain ranges that have since been inverted or eroded, and currently expose the deepest structural levels, or roots, of the original mountain range at the surface of the Earth. As such, in an attempt to better understand the processes that take place near the base of large mountain ranges, this collaborative project completed by faculty and undergraduate students at Queens College and Cal Poly San Luis Obispo, investigated the exposed roots of the Greenland Caledonides, a mountain range that spanned the length of Greenland, and formed as Scandinavia collided with North America from 440–360 million years ago.

Our field mapping and subsequent analytical results collected during the course of this project have yielded a number of interesting results with implications for the evolution of the Caledonides and other large mountain ranges. First, our data suggests that the rocks East Greenland experienced variable periods of burial and high-temperature metamorphism leading up to their collision with Scandinavia. In the west, and at the latitude of this study, this burial was relatively short-lived and ended prior to the ultimate continental collision, while farther east and in the core of the growing mountain range, high temperatures persisted up until continental impact. Second, upon continental impact, deep crustal rocks from both impacting continents were rapidly exhumed together via displacement along a series of crustal-scale faults. This rapid exhumation was possibly related to the pre-existing hot, and thus weak, continental crust within Greenland leading up to the collision. In addition, in an unexpected result unrelated to the evolution of the Caledonian mountains, we have dated 3.64 billion year old rocks in East Greenland. This previously unknown fragment of continental crust preserved from the early Earth represents one of a handful of localities worldwide where rocks older than 3.6 billion years old have been identified, and future study of this terrane have the potential to reveal new insights on the evolution of the early Earth. These results have been presented at national meetings in preliminary form, will be submitted for publication in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and will be of particular interest to researchers studying deformation in actively deforming mountain belts like the Himalaya and the geodynamics of the early Earth. Finally, this project has provided an opportunity for four Cal Poly undergraduate students to gain first-hand research experience in preparation for careers in the Earth Sciences, while supporting laboratory improvements at Cal Poly that will be used by future students in numerous subsequent projects.
